<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>

It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_get_device_property:
```c
int metal_linux_get_device_property(struct metal_device *device,
				    const char *property_name,
				    void *output, int len)
{
	int fd = 0;
	int status = 0;
	const int flags = O_RDONLY;
	const int mode = S_IRUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IROTH;
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/of_node/%s",
			 ldev->sdev->path, property_name);
	fd = open(path, flags, mode);
	if (fd < 0)
		return -errno;
	if (read(fd, output, len) < 0) {
		status = -errno;
		close(fd);
		return status;
	}

	status = close(fd);
	return status < 0 ? -errno : 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: property_name is already const-qualified (const char *), so it satisfies the rule; output is passed to read() and is used as a writeable destination, so it cannot be const; flags and mode are integer constants (not pointer types) so the rule does not apply; path is a local array (char path[PATH_MAX]) rather than a pointer type; file-descriptor variables and return-value handling involve integer types, not pointers. Therefore the only locations that may violate the requirement that pointers should point to const-qualified types are the function parameter and local pointer assignments shown above.
